review.title: An Innovative Imputation and Classification Approach for Accurate Disease Prediction
review.abstract: Imputation of missing attribute values in medical datasets for extracting hidden knowledge from medical datasets is an interesting research topic of interest which is very challenging. One cannot eliminate missing values in medical records. The reason may be because some tests may not been conducted as they are cost effective, values missed when conducting clinical trials, values may not have been recorded to name some of the reasons. Data mining researchers have been proposing various approaches to find and impute missing values to increase classification accuracies so that disease may be predicted accurately. In this paper, we propose a novel imputation approach for imputation of missing values and performing classification after fixing missing values. The approach is based on clustering concept and aims at dimensionality reduction of the records. The case study discussed shows that missing values can be fixed and imputed efficiently by achieving dimensionality reduction. The importance of proposed approach for classification is visible in the case study which assigns single class label in contrary to multi-label assignment if dimensionality reduction is not performed.

metadata.title: An Innovative Imputation and Classification Approach for Accurate Disease Prediction

sections.text: Keywords - attribution; missing values; prediction; nearest neighbor, cluster, medical records, dimensionality reductionI. INTRODUCTION Pre-processing of medical records is an important step that cannot be avoided in most situations and in the handling of medical records. Attributes included in medical records can be of different data types. Also, the values of attributes have a specific range that requires corresponding medical knowledge to handle them. This is because the handling of medical records is quite challenging for data miners and researchers. The various pre-processing techniques for medical records include identifying outliers in medical data, estimating and implementing missing values, normalizing medical attributes, using smoothing techniques to specify values of medical records to specify some of them.Data quality depends on data pre-processing techniques.

sections.heading: A. Research Objective
sections.text: We have the following research goals in this research to find missing values • Obviously our first and foremost goal is to ascribe missing values. • The goal is to reduce the dimensionality of medical records. • Classify new medical records using the same approach that is used to search for missing values. • Group medical records to assign similar records to a group.

sections.heading: B. Problem Specification
sections.text: Given a data set of medical records with and without missing values, the research goal is to address any missing values in medical records by using a novel efficient imputation approach based on the clustering of normal medical records to estimate missing values in medical records with missing values. The importance of the current approach we would like to propose has the following advantages. • The method can be used to find missing attribute values from medical records. • The same approach to detecting missing values can be used to classify medical records. • The disease prediction can be achieved with the proposed approach without having to adopt a separate procedure.

sections.heading: A. Handling Medical Datasets
sections.text: Research should begin by studying the benchmark data sets. Sometimes, it may be necessary to collect data from the ground up when we are working on a particular problem. However, when we are working with medical data sets, we must not forget that the data set is diverse.

sections.heading: B. Handling Missing Values in Medical Datasets
sections.text: The medical records are not free of missing values. Obviously, there is no free lunch. We need to make sure that the missing values are handled appropriately and accurately. A simple approach would be to discard the entire record, which essentially contains the missing value of an attribute. Some significant new approaches include [6-8, 12-14].

sections.heading: C. Choice of Prediction and Classifications algorithms
sections.text: The underlying data set is the decisive factor for the choice of the algorithm. A single classification algorithm is not suitable for every data set. Recent work includes [18-19].

sections.heading: D. Finding Nearest Medical Record and Identifying the Class Label
sections.text: Since the classification includes training and testing phases, the training data set must include all possible combinations that form a knowledge base in which the class label is accurately valued. Searching for the closest data sets can be done by using KNN classifiers or other classifiers. Classification can have a curse of dimensionality, so dimensionality reduction needs to be addressed appropriately. However, this can make the situation complex and sometimes inaccurate if important attribute information or attributes are overlooked or discarded [9-11].

sections.heading: E. Deciding on Medical Attributes
sections.text: The attributes of the medical dataset are also the main concern in predicting and classifying. This is because the attributes are multivariants [11]. One of the important tasks is also to identify the critical attributes for predicting heart disease that can have a significant impact on the classification accuracy and prediction of disease symptoms. In short, it is necessary to conduct a thorough literature survey to determine the attributes that must be taken into account and that can be discarded.

sections.heading: F. Removal of Noise
sections.text: Once we have determined the number of attributes, we can have one or more attributes that may not be important and can therefore be discarded without loss. Every effort must be made in this direction so that the attributes that are of the least importance and the removal of the attributes do not have a significant impact can be eliminated. 24 https: / / sites.google.com / site / ijcsis / ISSN 1947-5500IV. IMPUTATION FRAME WORK In this section we discuss the framework for the inclusion of incorrect values, as shown in Fig.2 and Fig.3The framework for missing values imputation consists of the following steps. The approach to missing values is based on the concept of clustering medical records without missing values. This is because all similar medical records are grouped in a cluster and therefore the imputation carried out should be more accurate. This approach to detecting missing values was not previously used in the literature.

sections.heading: A. Generating Clusters from Group
sections.text: • This step involves determining the number of class labels and creating clusters corresponding to the number of class labels • The clusters can be created using the k-mean algorithm by specifying the value of k as the number of class labels. Alternatively, we can apply any cluster algorithm that can create k clusters.

sections.heading: B. Computing distance of normal records to Cluster Centers
sections.text: • Determine the mean value of each cluster. This should be the cluster center • Get the distance of each medical file to each cluster center. • Summarize all obtained distances • The result is that all medical records are mapped to a single value, thereby achieving a dimensionality reduction.

sections.heading: C. Computing distance of missing records to Cluster Centers
sections.text: • Remove any medical record with missing values to each cluster center by discarding these attributes with missing values. • Sum of all distances obtained • The result is that all medical records are mapped to a single value, thereby reducing the dimensionality. • The method preserves information about the attributes.

sections.heading: D. Find Nearest Record to Impute Missing Values
sections.text: Consider each missing record in the group, G2 one by one. Calculate the distance of this record to all records in group G1. The record to which the distance is minimal is the closest neighbor. Calculate the missing attribute value taking into account the corresponding attribute value of the next record 25 https: / / sites.google.com / site / ijcsis / ISSN 1947-5500 in this class. The frequency can also be taken into account for the attribution because we have more than one neighbor. V. PROPOSED IMPUTATION ALGORITHM

Classify the records into two groups, say G1 and G2. The first group, G1 is separated from all medical records provided by Eq.1. The second group, G2 is considered as a test set in this case.
